Award.AwardTitle: Functional Specialization of the Mediator-Associated Kinases CDK8 and CDK19

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit: A major challenge in modern biology is to elucidate the molecular mechanisms employed by cells to regulate expression of thousands of genes in various contexts. Accurate regulation of gene activity is a key element of every major biological process. Specialized protein machineries regulate gene activity by decoding the information carried in DNA to satisfy the ever-changing needs of the cell. One such protein complex, known as Mediator, is recognized as a critical regulator of gene activity from yeast to humans, yet little is known about its mechanism of action. This research project investigates the function of two proteins within the Mediator complex, CDK8 and CDK19. Preliminary results demonstrate that CDK8 and CDK19 regulate the activity of different groups of genes involved in diverse cellular functions. This project aims to define the molecular mechanisms by which CDK8 and CDK19 enable cells to adjust the activity of different gene sets in response to changes in the cellular environment. This research is expected to have a transformative impact on the understanding of Mediator in particular and the evolution of gene expression control mechanisms in general. Given the quasi-universal role of Mediator in the control of gene activity, the discoveries arising from this project will have far reaching implications in the fields of cellular and molecular biology. Moreover, the innovative techniques developed in this project for the study of Mediator in human cells will produce a positive ripple effect in the gene expression field by enabling similar studies of other gene regulators.

Broader Impacts: This project is carried out by a teaching-research team that strongly promotes science education and diversity in academia. This collaborative team involves trainees at the undergraduate, graduate and post-doctoral levels who work in an environment displaying gender balance and inclusion of minorities. Both the host institution and the Principal Investigator participate actively in programs that aim to: a) increase the number of minority students earning PhDs, b) provide hands-on research experience to undergraduates, c) prepare undergraduate students to pursue PhDs in the biosciences, and d) increase the representation of women in leadership positions in academia. The success of these endeavors is documented by multiple undergraduate authors in the high impact publications from this laboratory and by the fact that most of the 30+ undergraduates trained in this group have advanced to graduate school, medical school or teaching positions. The Principal Investigator is an active member of the local Hispanic community and a recognized life science educator at the University of Colorado at Boulder, where he is the Instructor of a large undergraduate course and co-Instructor of several graduate courses. Members of this team promote scientific literacy in the public via regular contributions to the popular press and outreach activities at the state and national level.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Accurate regulation of gene activity is a key element of every major biological process, and a major challenge in modern biology is to understand the molecular mechanisms employed by cells in all life forms to regulate expression of thousands of genes in different contexts. Specialized protein machines regulate gene expression by synthesizing RNA molecules using DNA as a template to satisfy the ever changing needs of cells and organisms. One such protein machine, known as the Mediator complex, is recognized as a critical regulator of gene expression and is conserved from yeast to humans, yet little is known about its mechanism of action. This research project investigated the human version of the Mediator complex. More specifically, the project focused on two proteins within this molecular machine, which are known as CDK8 and CDK19.

Our research demonstrated that although CDK8 and CDK19 are very similar proteins in structure (in fact they arose from a single ancestral protein), they nonetheless have very specialized functions in gene expression control inside human cells. We found that they interact with different sets of proteins within the cell to regulate genes involved in diverse biological processes. For example, we found that CDK8, but not so CDK19, is required to mount an appropriate cellular response to conditions of low oxygen (i.e. hypoxia), thus allowing cells to survive during periods where this key nutrient is lacking. Our research also revealed many new aspects of the mechanism of action of these two proteins, which were very unanticipated, leading to high impact publications in the field.

This award has supported research in the Espinosa lab since March 2013, supporting a total of 25 scientific publications over four years. Seven of these publications are directly related to the work on the Mediator complex, with the other publications being synergistically supported and more directly related to other research projects in the lab. Of the 25 publications during this period, 19 are original research articles and 6 are invited reviews/previews.

Since March 2013, this award has contributed to the professional development of numerous trainees, including 11 post-doctoral fellows, 2 graduate students, and 22 undergraduate research assistants. Importantly, this NSF award has allowed the Espinosa laboratory to support the participation and training of women and underrepresented groups in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Medicine (STEM): of the numerous trainees supported directly or indirectly by this award, more than half are female, and nine are members of other groups underrepresented in STEM.  Also, during the award period, the Principal Investigator Dr. Joaquin Espinosa was promoted to Professor in the Department of Pharmacology at the University of Colorado Anschutz Medical Campus. Dr. Matthew Galbraith, who originally participated in the project as a post-doctoral fellow, now holds a faculty appointment as an Instructor in the Department of Pharmacology at the University of Colorado Anschutz Medical Campus. This award supported the training of graduate student Katherine Audetat, an honorably discharged US Marine Corps Veteran, who recently defended her PhD thesis. In addition, this award helped with training of several undergraduate students who have been accepted into graduate schools across the U.S.
